discussion.title: The 100 best novels written in English: the full list

comments.body: This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our community standards. Replies may also be deleted. For more detail see our FAQs.
Could you BEany more subjective, isneet
I find, to my dismay, that I've read a third of this peculiar, eclectic mix of pretention and populism, although it contains only two of my personal favourite novels...

responses.body: Is it not just a list of 100 books, "some of which I have read".

comments.body: I've already railed against Ulysses, but I'm surprised that the list starts so late. Morte D'Arthur I would have thought was worth a shout. Especially the poignancy of the ending - it's all been an upbeat romp with occasional actual romps (usually ending tragically), but the whole thing comes crashing down after its peak and we are back to real humans with real frailties and a memory of an ungraspable paradise.

responses.body: Does Morte D'Arthur count, though? It's really a translated compilation of stories written in French...

It's a lot more than that. The Grail, Perceval, Balyn & Balan and Arthur himself all originate in Germano-Celtic myth, probably Tristan as well; the main French-derived character is Lancelot. But its scope is far more vast than any single instance that has gone before. Melding courtly love onto the dog-eat-dog mysticism of the Grail mythos. And the Gareth arc seems to be solely Malory's, he was a very different chap in earlier stories.

Does Morte D'Arthur count, though? It's really a translated compilation of stories written in French...

Despite its title, Morte d'Arthur was written in English. However, you are right that it is not a novel by most standards.

How can you rail against Ulysses? It's utterly brilliant. I didn't realise how good it was until Scylla and Charybdis - the Shakespeare chapter - and then it suddenly dawned on me that I was reading a masterpiece. It can make us laugh on almost every page and Bloom and Stephen are such universal characters that we can find tiny fragments of ourselves in their experiences. It might be tricky to read at first, but when you're compiling a list of the best/greatest novels, Ulysses has to be on there.
Yes, I must admit to a certain understating of its importance. Still, though, I would hesitate to include it in a list like this.

Sorry, clumsy wording. It's a translation into English of a collection of stories that were originally written in French (among other languages, to be more precise), as I understand it.

Definitely work collecting into a list of the 100 best books, rather than the 100 best novels. But then I would include The Very Hungry Caterpillar in the 100 best books...

comments.body: The joy of this list is that most of the really good books on here were written by women. It's a crying shame that Margaret Atwood's Cat's Eye, Alice Walker's The Colour Purple, Toni Morrisson's Jazz, and Richard Yates' Revolutionary Road aren't on there. I've also heard nothing but praise for Patricia Highsmith's Ripley series. But we've all got our own list, don't we?

responses.body:
Over these I'd put Carson McCullers, maybe Ballad of the Sad Café (even though my personal favourite of hers is Clock Without Hands). Revolutionary Road is a great call though.

How about Stoner? I know I'm bandwagon-jumping but it's one of the best I've read lately.

comments.body: I'm surprised that 'Spot The Dog' by Eric Hill isn't on this list.

responses.body: The hungry Catapillar is a far superior work, the heft of the backstory and the broad arc of the character transformation is on a different level.

If you're looking for story arc I'd recommend Bears on Wheels. The ever persistent one bear on one wheel, traversing the road, encountering various combinations of bears and wheels is like a pre-school Don Quixote; and within the context, the culmination of (spoiler alert) '21 on none' followed by 'one on one again', is the ideal climax/denouement.
Why is this not on the list?
Everyone says that book is great but Eric Carle's work is just not to my taste. I got half-way through 'The Grouchy Ladybug' and stopped reading it as I just couldn't relate to any of the characters.
Sounds familiar. Have you read 'Dogger' by Shirley Hughes by any chance? One of the great works of feminist literature.
I'll see you your The Hungry Caterpillar (and nnn's Spot The Dog) and raise you a Freight Train by Donald Crews. Reading it will...well move you.
will have to check it out. Just finished Solzhenitsyn's Gulag Archipelago and looking for something a bit lighter.
Nor is Robert McCloskey's 'Make Way for Ducklings'. A seminal work.

comments.body: I'm intrigued that Robert McCrum includes genre fiction, but only the criminal kind. Ballard, Vonnegut, LeGuin, Dick have written speculative fiction with literary competence, even style, and with a scintillating breadth of ideas: where are they?

responses.body:
This list is about maintaining the cultural elite's stranglehold on what is to be regarded as acceptable reading matter.

It's a list of 100 cultural hoops that the socially aspiring are expected to jump through in order to have a chance of joining their 'intellectual betters'.

...also William Gibson and Ian (M). Banks criminally missing!
No Potter and the Tree of Nothing, thank goodness.

The list does include Dracula, Frankenstein, Dorian Gray, Brave New World and Nineteen Eighty-Four, so it's not like he hasn't included any SF or fantasy at all, but yes, it's a shame not to see any more true genre classics - no The Dispossessed, Dune, Stranger in a Strange Land, Fahrenheit 451, Man in the High Castle, Lord of the Rings, The Midwich Cuckoos etc.

As always with these lists, it's very po-faced too. Apart from Three Men in a Boat, Joy in the Morning and Alice in Wonderland there's almost nothing fun. I enjoyed Hitch Hiker's Guide to the Galaxy more than almost anything in this list.

McCrum has written a round-up piece on these pages, in which he expresses regret for omitting Ballard and Vonnegut, among others. He went as far as to say Slaughterhouse 5 "should have been in there", but that he was too generous to the 1880-1930 window earlier in the series.
Yes! Hitch Hiker's. Not the greatest literature, but surely one of the most influential books of recent years!

Apart from Three Men in a Boat, Joy in the Morning and Alice in Wonderland there's almost nothing fun.

That depends on your notion of fun. I think quite a lot of the books on the list are fun.

Of course I have to put in a vote for my creator, Orson Scott Card, although the novel named after me isn't as popular as Ender's Game, whilst Speaker for the Dead deserves far more visibility: as the winner of the Hugo and Nebula awards the year after Ender's Game won both, it is truly special to have achieved that unique double.

A more obvious candidate given that it is by a woman and has a strong feminist theme is 'Left Hand of Darkness' which focuses on a culture where there are only andogyns, neither men nor women but becoming one or other at the time of mating.

Ender's Game is brilliant, and Speaker is nearly as good (more interesting from an SF perspective in many ways, but less so as a story), but I'm not sure either of them ranks quite up there in the stratospheric heights of others in the list.

Unfortunately, for me Ender is slightly tainted by its author's political views. I try not to let it bother me (the book itself doesn't suffer from them) but I can't quite manage to dissociate the two.

I never quite engaged with Left Hand of Darkness; The Dispossessed is still my favourite Ursula LeGuin by far, possibly my favourite SF novel of all time. It's an important reference point for me in my thoughts on sociology and human nature; everything SF should be about. It gets a little woolly at the end, but it's streets ahead of any other utopian fiction.

"He explained to Atro that he now understood why the army was organised as it was. It was indeed quite necessary. No rational form of organisation would serve the purpose. He simply had not understood that the purpose was to enable men with machine guns to kill unarmed men and women easily and in great quantities when told to do so"
HHGG or H2G2 reigns supreme sort of.
Agreed - Slaughterhouse five is outstanding.
Scoop is laugh out loud funny. Don't read it in a 'quiet' carriage or room.
Yes, I missed Scoop in my list of humorous books - and A Clockwork Orange from the SF. Probably a few more too.

comments.body: Too much old stuff!

responses.body: I agree - if this is his personal favourites, that's fair enough but in terms of 'best novels' - what was the critieria ??????
Yeah! Nobody cares about Henry Fielding or Charlotte Bronte. Where's Dan Brown? Where's Andy McNab?
Yeah! I recon that Zoella book should be in there.

comments.body: Glad to see 'Wuthering Heights' up there, and even happier that there is no sign of the overrated 'Pride and Prejudice'!

responses.body: And yet we have Scoop and no Brideshead?

comments.body: It is a truth universally acknowledged that Emma is not the only great novel that Jane Austen wrote.

responses.body:
Hhm. Seems there was a deliberate decision to list only one book by each novelist. Might have been better to call it a list of 100 greatest novelists then.


Speaking of taste, I selected, where possible, the title most central to the author’s voice and vision, which is not necessarily the most famous. Consider Jane Austen. Pride and Prejudice is much loved. Northanger Abbey is highly entertaining. Some readers revere Sense and Sensibility. But I chose Emma.

Casual browsers sometimes took a moment to grasp that my list of “top novels” was: a) derived exclusively from fiction written in the English language; b) strictly chronological; and c) gave each writer equal space, an especially restrictive criterion.
Although since there's only one novel by each author on the list, it is probably worth acknowledging the truth that Emma is Austen's greatest novel.

Hmmmm. I guess I should read it again. I've probably been annoyed by the adaptions. It is hard to go past:

... how peculiarly unlucky poor Mr. Elton was in being in the same room at once with the woman he had just married, the woman he had wanted to marry, and the woman whom he had been expected to marry, ...

for great lines.

Agreed. Emma was the first Austen I ever read, so I suppose I have a bit of a soft spot for it. They're all brilliant, truth be told, and I never understand why people (especially young people) are so dismissive of Austen.

Because most of her work is shallow and single track based upon the pursuit of social acceptance. The depths of the human psyche George Elliot plumbed far outstrips the materialistic upper class world of Austen.
Austen was probably our greatest writer of superior, witty airport novels.
IMHO Mansfield Park is the Austen work which could be described as a great novel.

IMHO Mansfield Park is the Austen work which could be described as a great novel.

And I would argue that the Patricia Rozema (1999) version of Mansfield Park is the best of the film adaptations of Austen's work, too!

comments.body: Where the Dickens is Dickens???

responses.body: David Copperfield's on there, but you're right - there should have been more.
I quite agree - listing David Copperfield is not enough! Also the list shows a male tendency and doesn't do justice to hundreds of other stunning works by women and men authors.
He wrote nothing worth reading.
This was covered somewhere in the rationale for the list - he restricted himself to one book per author.
Is David Copperfield Dickens' best? Better than Great Expectations, Little Dorrit, Bleak House ... ?

Charles Dickens wrote nothing worth reading?

Even by CIF standards, that statement is beyond stupid.
Better ask Robert McCrum that! My own Dickens experience is limited to Pickwick and Hard Times (to my shame I've only read junior abridged versions of Twist, Copperfield).
It is a personal opinion. But thanks for the insult.

comments.body: No Arnold Bennett. Why?

responses.body: crumb doesn't rate Bennett - but hails virginia wolff
please feel free to replace the great gatsby with the old wives' tale

comments.body: Glad at least a few of these are on my list. http://worstwriter.com/library/

responses.body: No George Eliot and only two plays by T.S.? And two books by Malcolm Gladwell?!
Middlemarch? number 21
I was referring to the list posted at the start of this thread, not Robert's.

comments.body: Has the creator of this list actually read Robinson Crusoe? The ending is a mess. Good novel? yes. Great novel? perhaps. Number two? No bloody way.

responses.body: It's ordered by date I think not best to last.
EDIT: Sorry I meant "not best to worst".

comments.body: I would largely agree with someone who made a good case for its conservatism, though not made by a nasty little Trot who deserves only to be dropped out of a helicopter...
Would have liked to see 'Things Fall Apart' on the list - and what is Rudyard Kipling doing on there, yuk.

responses.body:
Why "yuk" to Kipling? I'm going to make the assumption that it's because of his cultural attitudes, rather than his literary qualities. (Mainly because "yuk" sounds to me like an emotional judgement.)

If this is the case, then try reading Kim again, but from a modern viewpoint - and appreciate and enjoy it as a work of its time, and the perspective it gives you on colonial thinking. I can thoroughly recommend a recent edition (Penguin, I think) with a wonderful introduction by Edward Said, who is the very last person that you could accuse of being an apologist for colonialism!

comments.body: Where is the Lord of the Rings and why Artist of the Floating World and not the Remains of the Day for a book by Ishiguro?

responses.body: Agree with you about Remains of the Day, but I much prefer the Hobbit to LotR, mainly because there's only one bloody Hobbit in it. Is there a bigger kiss arse in all of literature than Sam Gamgee?
Sam is ok, Frodo is an annoying whiny little git.

The Hobbit is far better written. The Lord of the Rings is one of the best stories ever told, but some of the writing completely goes to pieces, especially towards the end - he seems to be experimenting with different styles throughout the book.
Agree about Frodo, but Sam is worse for sucking up to him the whole time when he should have given him a slap and told him to get over his self.

Sam is the greatest hero in LOTR as he was the only one who was able to shake off the power of the ring & not become corrupted by it. Others became corrupted by it without actually having worn it.

Sam is the epitome of a moral life trumping the temptation of absolute power & it was his character that enabled him to stave off the power of the ring, along with his extraordinary resilience he demonstrated along the way.
mervyn peake anyone?

comments.body: Has Thomas Wolfe gone down the memory hole?

responses.body: The absence of Bonfire of the Vanities (if we discount The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test and The Right Stuff since they're not technically novels) was one of the list's most disappointing omissions, in my opinion, particularly when a mediocre novelist like Ishiguro gets on there.
I believe the reference was to Thomas Wolfe not Tom Wolfe.
Which indicates that Thomas Wolfe has indeed gone down the memory hole...
And yet Tom Wolfe survives. It's a funny old world.
Ah. My bad.
Bonfire of the Vanities a great read.

comments.body:
Oh, there are so many great titles missing but well, bless you for coming up with this list. I'd have chosen The Pickwick Papers from Dickens, a forever favourite of mine.
-a bookworm

responses.body:
Oh, there are so many great titles missing but well, bless you for coming up with this list. I'd have chosen The Pickwick Papers from Dickens, a forever favourite of mine.
-a bookworm


--It makes me wonder why only one of Dickens' novels is on the list ( David Copperfield). There are so many others that could be considered better.
Also, I wonder why he chose Faulkner's As I Lay Dying instead of, say, The Sound and the Fury, a much better novel I think, or even Light in August.
I think Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man deserves to be there with Ulysses; Ishiguro's Never Let Me Go or even The Remains of the Day.
I've never read any George Gissing but I know one of my professors wrote a dissertation on him.

comments.body: Is this to say there hasn't been a single book worthy of being in the top 100 in the past 15 years

responses.body: No. He decided to finish at 2000.

comments.body:
Did I miss it? Is Robert Tressell's, "The Ragged Trousered Philanthropists", on this list?

It all seems, terribly, middle-class, to me.

responses.body: It's a bit "off message" with the Guardian these days......

Time was in any interview with any Labour politician that books came up TRTP would get a mention as being absolutely pivotal and life changing , these days they tend to look at Blairs bank balance for inspiration .
I loved that book! (Still do)
TRTP is, I think, a good book, not a great book, that ought to have been published in Tressell's lifetime. And, if it had, probably would have benefitted from an editor.

comments.body: i've read 16 from the list, which is a bit crap. And Thomas Pynchon didn't make the cut while Don DeLillo did? Underworld probably his worst book, too.

responses.body: Which Pynchon would you include, out of interest? I think the choice of a Pynchon novel says a lot about the reader :)

Says a lot about the reader's age as well
I'd choose Gravity's Rainbow, but I know several people from a younger generation who would choose Mason and Dixon.
The P-list recently had a ranking thread and those two came out on top.
For me, GR is the only Pynchon that is essential reading. I positively disliked The Crying of Lot 49.

Yes, I agree. GR is a book driven by passion, all of his youthful vision, political, philosophical and aesthetic, painted onto the page in glorious demented prose.
I know people who have said it fundamentally changed the way they saw the world. It is more than a novel, it is a revolutionary tract, even as it acknowledges that we have little hope of defeating the beast.
Vineland is a sadder, wiser coda, hoping the next generation can do more.
I like all his other books to a greater or lesser degree, but GR is the one I reread, and dip into and read sections thereof far more than I do all the others put together.

Still as far as this list goes all we can say is McCrum was clearly not affected that way ;-)
I love trying to explain the plot to people...
Intellectuals' party game - describe GR in twenty five words or less.
Jesus, just thinking about it makes my head hurt!

Gravity's Rainbow for me, although I loved Mason and Dixon. And Against the day is almost as stupendous as GR. My original post was really that of all the quite brilliant DeLillo books he could have chosen (White Noise; Running Dog; Ratner's Star), he chose the one enormous book he ever wrote. DeLillo - unlike Pynchon - is not so good over the longer distance, whereas Pynchon fumbles the short: The Crying Of Lot 49 being the un-shining example. There. A long time to make a small point...
He was pretty disparaging of Lot 49 later but IMO it is full of wonders and for anyone interested in Pynchon I reckon it is a good place to start.
What about V? I quite liked that one. Although GR is excellent.

My introduction to Pynchon was a guy who used to stand at the bar where I worked reading V and telling me it was the greatest book ever written. I was keen on Richard Farina's Been Down So Long ...and enthused about that. He dismissed it - not into books based on song titles, he said. I have often wondered what he thought when GR was published and he saw the dedication to Farina.
V too is excellent, in fact I think only his last two have been weak, in comparison to all his others.

comments.body: Read the top 10 and found it too staid and old fashioned to continue.

responses.body: No great surprise there as they are in chronological order !
So you didn't realise that they're listed in chronological order, oldest first.
I should have included a ;) or something to make it clearer I was joking
Was just a joke, but I guess it was a bit too realistic seeming
Sorry :-(
Odd I thought they were listed in order of nationality; English writers first then American.

comments.body: Midnight's Children was quite good. The Catcher in the Rye was one of the worst books I ever read. I haven't read any of the other ninety-eight and don't intend to. Looks like mostly litfic, a genre I can't abide.

responses.body: It's been a long time since I read Catcher, but I thought it was wonderful. I've always been surprised, though, that so many people take it literally. For me it was always obvious that Holden is a tragic character - surrounded by decent, loving people, all of whom he dismisses as 'phonies', caught up in his own teenage angst and unable to accept any emotion as genuine. But most of the commentaries I've seen seem to take his own word for it that he's the only one seeing the world as it really is.
So glad to meet the only other person on the planet who hates The Catcher in the Rye.

Don't so much hate it as completely indifferent..... I can only surmise that the style and content of the book were somewhat original at the time, but I am afraid it gets a great big "Meh" from me....
A suitable boy or anything by Mistry far better than Midnight's Children

I read Catcher in the Rye a little over a year ago for the first time and thought it was excellent; not ground shaking from my point of view, but then I don't live in 50s America.
Like most works, it helps to try and put it into its cultural and temporal context, if you want to understand why it was regarded as revolutionary.
Even as it stands, however, in this day and age, it's a superb exercise in character study, which is why it's so often imitated.
But then I would say that cos I'm a bastard and a phony.

comments.body: Read 49 of them. Not sure what that says about me though......

responses.body: It says to me that you are the world's fastest reader
You've done time in solitary with a limited library available to you?

"It says to me that you are the world's fastest reader"

My bookshelves have over 2000 books. I have pruned probably another 1000. That doesn't count the continual supply of library books as a child before I could afford to buy them. Only a few of the most recent purchases have not been read completely - retirement seems to have less reading time available than when I was working.

I've read many of the books in the list - but wouldn't rate some of them particularly highly. "Catcher in the Rye" was supposed to appeal to teenage boys but made no impression on me in the VIth Form. John Steinbeck's "Cannery Row" was a far more enjoyable read.
I completely agree about Cannery Row, brilliant little novel.

Many congrats.

Yes, Cannery Row is excellent

(Withnail and I) x
(On the Road)
_____________________________________ = Cannery Row

√the ocean

Well, you obviously like to read ;-)
For a closer analysis you would have to list the numbers of those you have read.

comments.body: Trainspotting....?

Well that could have been written by an A-level Eng Lit student...

2/3 of these are from post-1900 - how deeply unimaginative

responses.body: That sort of makes sense, though, there must have been many more novels written since then. And more people with a great novel inside them would have been able to write them and get them published. After all, we never did get to read "Edmund, A Butler's Tale", crammed with hot gypsies.

You think? I believe it's very unlikely that the average A level student will have read more than a small fraction of these.

And I would speculate that more than 2/3 of all novels published in English have been published since 1900.

comments.body: Some bloke lists his favourite books. Yawn.

responses.body: Some bloke on the internet chips in on a blog even though he's got bugger all to say. Yawn.

Actually, some bloke not only lists his favourite books but includes links to interesting and informative reviews he has written on each one of them (all one hundred).

Personally, I don't find it appropriate, or indeed logical, to sneer at someone who has put in all that useful effort.
Just because someone has put effort in a completely pointless exercise, they deserve praise?
If people have enjoyed it - how can it be described as pointless ?
By dismissing two years worth of work on this list, I don't think you could have been any more cruel or vindictive.
No, that's not cruelty; cruelty has to contain the power to wound. This is just someone being sour and joyless and making himself look like a total prick.

comments.body:
1) Define 'best'
2) Define 'novels'
3) Go and have a lie down
4) Enjoy reading books

This seems to be a list of mostly:
1. - I really should read that, because everybody says it's something I should have read.
2. - I really should read that, but I'll watch the film instead.
3. - Never heard of it.
4. - Oh - that was a book was it?!
What, no Fifty Shades? Every woman I've met over 40 assures me it's a masterpiece...

responses.body: Forever Amber

comments.body: Well lists can only ever be subjective and a mild entertainment. Though this one oddly ends in 2000 implying nothing of merit has been written in the last 15 years - which is obviously ludicrous. A rather pompous catalogue of canon literature - the first 30 read like an english undergraduate's essential reading list.

responses.body: If you read the article by the person who composed the list he just chose to stop at 2000. So really it is the "100 best novels written in English up to 2000 inclusive". Not a snappy enough title I guess.

The title is even more inaccurate, given that each author only gets one book in the list, so it's not even '100 best novels' - it's 'A selection of novels written in English by the 100 best authors'. I know it doesn't really matter, but these things annoy me. The content of the list does not reflect the title of the list any more than if I published 'The 10 best fruit', thus:
1. Pineapple
2. Cherry
3. Carrot
4. Chocolate cake
5. Strawberry
6. Bakewell pudding
7. Lemon
8. Melon
9. Raspberry
10. Cheese
Can't believe Strawberry made it in at number 5 mate. You're having a laugh. You know nothing about fruit. You are just pandering to popular taste. Also, Tony Blair is a terrible man.
Orange is not y the only fruit then?
It's chronological. I'm not saying it's the 5th best fruit.

This is one of the stupidest comments I've ever read on the Guardian. If you read the author's columns, you would have noticed that he said it was the best English language novels, and that like all lists, it would be subjective. Maybe if you paid more attention to what you read, then you wouldn't waste our time with such lousy comments.

Wow, I've sure pissed you off, haven't I?

you would have noticed that he said it was the best English language novels

I did notice this, thanks. But I also noticed that they're not 'the best English language novels', because the list stops at 2000, and the list only includes one book by each author, which was my point.
You're just being fruitist.
Sorry. I now feel (and look) like a complete arse.

Ha ha. No harm done. My main criticism is with the sub-editors for click-baiting the list. It's one more step towards a completely dumbed-down misleadingly over-sensationalised Buzzfeed style of churned-out content. Tell us what the list actually is, not what'll get most clicks.

A second (more minor) frustration is that I would very much like to see a list of the 100 best novels in English, which would surely be more interesting, and which this list isn't. If, in Mr McCrum's opinion, a single author was responsible for, say, 5 of the 10 best novels, I want to know. I know that the merit of a book is different from something more measurable like the time taken to run 100 metres, but still.

comments.body: So, books have gotten worse then.

responses.body: No, the list is chronological.

comments.body: It's all a bit stuffy... and Lolita should definitely be in the top ten...

responses.body: Good shout. Absolutely brilliant book.
The list is chronological?
Yes, it is ;-)
It's a historical list from oldest to newest

It's amazing how many people have not noticed this. You'd think that the fact that over 100 weeks the books became more and more modern would tip people off, or maybe even the fact that the publication dates are right next to the titles!
Yes, my stupidity - as I'd already sussed that - but suspect I was still thinking it was a "top 100", with the favourite at no.1. Go to bottom of class... :(

comments.body: Kudos for listing The Moonstone - It doesn't get the publicity it deserves, but listing Pilgrim's Progress destroys any credibility this list might otherwise have. It's the godawfulest drivel imaginable. Has anyone in this century (or the last for that matter) read it? I tried because it was very popular during the 19th century and it is terrible.

responses.body:
"Pilgrim's Progress" was compulsory reading at school in the 1950s.

At least the list didn't include "Eric -or Little by Little". No mention of "The Waterbabies" and "Tom Brown's School Days" which were classics.
I've read Pilgrim's Progress, and think it is a fascinating work - can't think of anything comparable to it. It has both a timeless and a naive quality - almost myth-like.

comments.body: I live in Burwash, so it's great that Kipling is mentioned, but I would have gone for Puck of Pooks Hill rather than Kim.

responses.body: is burwash pronounced burridge? ford madox ford claimed it was

That is the traditional dialect, and some of the older villagers still call themselves Burrishers, but it's largely died out now, which is a pity. I moved here from London 30 odd years ago and can't imagine living anywhere else, but wouldn't dare to claim the title for myself.

comments.body:
You can get a copy of The Pilgrim's Progress absolutely legal and free, here.

What a time to be alive!

19 so probably not qualified to comment, but at least there's no Ian McEwan the worst of the overhyped contemporary English novelists....

still a depressing thought, that Amis or Rushdie have written one of the 100 best novels in English....

responses.body: If you've read a book you are certainly qualified to comment

Of course, at 19, you are qualified to comment, especially if you read or are interested in books. You prove the point by the confidence and concision with which you express opinions about the novels of Ian McEwan, Martin Amis and Salman Rushdie, all of whom you don't seem to like, as is your right. If you don't mind, may I ask you which novels you like, which novelists you respect?

comments.body: Tolkien?

Scoop is not one of the top 100. Evelyn Waugh wrote several better books himself. Same can be said of the impenetrable Voss by Patrick White. Carey's Ned Kelly is not the best Kelly nor Carey's best novel. Where's Iris Murdoch, Patricia Highsmith, Le Carre? Not 'worthy'? Better than many of these.

responses.body:
Evelyn Waugh wrote several better books himself

Up to a point, Lord Copper.

I disagree about Voss. For me it is one of the greatest novels of the post-war era: a thrilling story written in rich, original prose about an extraordinary journey with some excellent social comedy thrown in for good measure. Yesterday some people complained about the lack of a post-1925 (?) novel in McCrum's top ten. This would be a contender for me (along with Lolita and Under the Volcano).
Voss bored me stiff. Couldn't finish it. Don Delillo much the same.

Patrick White as good a novelist as ANY on the list - and so says a Kiwi; even the lesser works such as The Twybourne Affair or The Aunt's Story are excellent; for most brilliant I would have chosen The Eye of the Storm or The Solid Mandala over Voss.

comments.body: You forgot all the Dan Brown books...

responses.body:
And J.K. Rowling.

Seriously though, as page turners any of the Harry Potter books are better than equally commercial books like The Thirty Nine Steps and Scoop which make the list. There is a huge older implies better bias in the list.

I don't see an 'older implies better' bias. From the 19th century there are usually only three or four titles per decade, whereas from, say, the 1960s there are 12. The 1980s have seven novels, the 1880s four.

Not sure that follows; as a percentage of the total number of books published in their time, the older ones certainly outweigh the newer. I definitely agree with tom's point that there's no real reason to include populist fiction of its time while excluding great examples of modern times. Harry Potter is easily as deserving as Alice in Wonderland.

comments.body: No Atwood! What criteria has been used ? As an English teacher I am always suspicious of the 'canon' as it is largely kept alive by GCSE and A level syllabi- especially in terms of annual sales, not by the power of the text on the reader. In these terms, for young people THE novel which is most likely to affect them and their thinking for the rest of their lives is 'Of Mice and Men' - probably one of the most powerful and moving texts ever written - yet 'The Grapes of Wrath" makes 'the' list yet again. Another writer who opens young minds and affects them for years to come is Robert Swindells. No Hosseini, Haddon or Faulks !! But yet again 'Little Women' - how many people have ever actually completed this except out of sheer bloody-mindedness ! Great novels are read 'freely' generation after generation: that's what makes them great - all these kinds of lists do is churn out the same old literary snobbery and ignores the stuff which really impacts on people's lives. Makes me quite angry when I see part of my job is to encourage young people to see reading as an exciting recreational activity long after they have left school.

responses.body:
Well, I have read 66 of these books 'freely' and 3 unfreely (O level - though I have returned to two of them freely in adult life), most of them with great pleasure.

I am surprised at the inclusion of Little Women, which I have recently read to my 10-year-old daughter. She seemed to enjoy it more than I did, though, and is keen to move onto the sequel.

The aim of the list is to get people talking and reading books they might not otherwise have encountered or chosen: I have read a couple of Thomas Love Peacock novels as a result of it, with some pleasure, though I certainly wouldn't put him in my top 100.

I'm not sure this list is as prescriptive as you believe, but in any case it's not supposed to be a list of 100 books for GSCE students or 100 books to guarantee young people "see reading as an exciting recreational activity long after they have left school", worthy as such a list might be. Anyway, there's quite a lot of very readable stuff on the list, but 'being of interest to a teenager' should not the primary criterion of literary quality. Similarly, a list of "the stuff which really impacts on people's lives" might be an entirely different list including, inter alia, the Highway Code, PACE, Magna Carta...

comments.body: JP Donleavy - Beastly Beatitudes of Balthazar B, I Claudius and Claudius the God by Robert Graves. Swallows and Amazons (actually Swallowdale perhaps the best).More Evelyn Waugh - Officer and a Gentleman trilogy. John Wyndam - The Kraken wakes.......

responses.body: Schulz, also by Donleavy, deserves to be there too. Mind you, so do hundreds of others .... this list of the best stuff is not especially revealing or even interesting, but the links more than justify it.

I can't judge Beastly Beatitudes fairly because it was one of my teenage wank-books - the sex scene between the young Balthazar and his nanny was very well-thumbed. Now I can't quite read it objectively!

comments.body: I've read 15 (well 13, with two in the process of being read atm) ☺

responses.body:
Yeah, around 15 for me too, although I can't be sure about a couple of them.

Enjoying all the pompous prigs expressing their outrage that the top ten are all old, that [insert favourite classic French/Russian/German novel here] is not included, that the list ends in 2000, and that all of Dickens' novels should be on there.

comments.body: Robert Graves , I Claudius , was he the first to write that kind of historical fiction ?, that led to the Flashman,s, Aubrey Maturin , Cadfael etc etc almost ad infinitum pure fiction set in an actual historical context ?

responses.body:
And no Flashman Bigod!

Which bounder produced this list anyway?
No. Dickens' wrote novels set in historical contexts. No idea who was first, though

Did Dickens characters interact with real historical characters though ? that is my point not that say Shakespeare wrote Antony and Cleopatra ? these are attempts i think at history not strictly historical fiction . I have spoken to people who thought Flashman was an actual person .

George Eliot wrote Romola in the early 1860s, and it's the earliest example of something I can think of that is a clearcut historical novel. I haven't read Defoe's Journal of the Plague Year though, and can't say if that would count or not, but sounds from the title as if it probably would.
Les Miserables is also a historical novel and was published a year before Romola.

comments.body: Seventy-six.

responses.body: Well done!! Which was best?

comments.body:
Forty-three.

It was thanks to this list that I read In Cold Blood last month. Very good.

responses.body: Same here. That was a great book.

comments.body: No William Burroughs. List is entirely invalid.

responses.body: Hardly. Naked Lunch is more important for changes to the obscenity law than as a piece of literature.
well that's the big problem with this list - it has a strong whiff of the british literary tradition - therefore no burroughs and no ballard

comments.body: Where's "First Ladies" by Kay Burley?

responses.body: you mean Kay Burley can write? God's teeth!

"First Ladies" is a modern day classic in which a TV new journalist who in no way resembles Kay Burley apart from looks and behaviour is seduced by a Prime Minister who in no way resembles David Cameron apart from looks and behaviour.

comments.body: To my eye any title on this list looks like a potential winning entry in the game Humiliation, described (I think) in Malcolm Bradbury's The History Man.

responses.body: Noooooo! David Lodge!!
The worst thing is that in McCrum's companion article to this full list, he starts by referring to Humiliation!

comments.body: A fascinating list, but in lieu of no. 93 by Martin Amis, I would offer Lucky Jim by his far more talented, educated and observant father.
Is there a rule of one book per author? Becuase Pride and Prejudice should be there too. Take off one of the later selections, like the Toni Morrison, which are not in the same league.

responses.body: I agree. I am a great Jane Austen fan and think that Pride and Prejudice is her best book. I would also put Persuasion above Emma.
Yes, that's one of the rules.

comments.body:
What an utterly pointless exercise. I've met a handful of people over the last dozen or so years whose reading is based on lists like these, startlingly they all have two things in common: no real passion for literature, but a fierce desire to be taken seriously around pompous people.

There is no real criteria for an exercise such as this. What exactly does it mean that Copperfield is rated more highly than Lolita? Nothing. They're very different books and which you prefer depends on personal taste. Anyway, I'm writing this because I think it's potentially damaging to people getting into literature to dictate too much what they should be reading. I've been countless people who've taken this route and have given up, and they now see reading as a chore. Far better, methinks, to talk to a friend who's a voracious read and knows you very well - for a more personalised recommendation.

responses.body: More than a ranking, it seems to be a chronological sorting. Otherwise it means the Guardian thinks we've been going downhill since 1678 !
I agree, but I should point out they're listed according to year of publication, not rating.
'David Copperfield' isn't rated higher than 'Lolita'. The list is in order of date of publication.

I've met a handful of people over the last dozen or so years whose reading is based on lists like these, startlingly they all have two things in common: no real passion for literature, but a fierce desire to be taken seriously around pompous people.

Blimey, What circles do you move in. I have enjoyed the list, selected and read books that looked of interest, and been introduced to new authors. I have also enjoyed the reviews and the BTL comments, including the at times baffling anger the list has evoked.

I thought the list was great, and well worth it as an exercise.

I'd agree with you if these people had based the entirety of their reading on the lists; however if they use them as a starting point to explore authors/styles/genres etc. then they can be very useful. If you walk into a bookshop or check the front page of Amazon you aren't going to get many works like these being promoted, so lists of 'best novels ever' can serve a purpose in giving those who haven't been lucky enough to seek out, stumble across or be taught any of them some awareness of their existence.

so lists of 'best novels ever' can serve a purpose in giving those who haven't been lucky enough to seek out, stumble across or be taught any of them some awareness of their existence

Quite.

Of course it's pointless. It's a list about art. It's putting subjectively-rated media into an objective order, which can never ever be anything more than a futile exercise.

But the point of this article is not to come up with a definitive, line in the sand categorisation. It's to get you, me and everyone else to have a discussion about the list. Which it has.

comments.body: There is a palpable lack of science fiction on this list. Alright there's Frankenstein and Nineteen Eighty-Four, but there's nothing from H.G. Wells, no Flatland, no Le Guin, Adams or Philip K. Dick. It is a very subjective list indeed.

responses.body: No Iain (M.) Banks as well !
Wow, its as if one person has compiled an entirely subjective list of their favourite books according to their opinion!
And absolutely no fantasy writing. A genre that has shaped generations passed over without a single mention!
No John Wyndham...and not even any Graham Greene.

comments.body:
I can't stop vomiting with disbelief that you didn't choose the same 100 books I would have chosen if I'd been compiling my top 100 books.

It's obviously proof of dumbing down and if anyone wants me I'll be in my study reading dead intellectual books by Dostoyesvky or Katie Price.

responses.body: To be fair to Katie Price she always manages to invoke the same amount of existential dread in me that Dostoyevsky does, and in considerably fewer words.

comments.body: Well I have enjoyed this list. It is the choice of one person and we would all choose a different list, but it has opened my eyes to a number of books (and authors) that I would not otherwise have read and for that - cheers Robert.

I am pleased to see Wind In the Willows included but am aghast at the exclusion of Richard Adams' Watership Down - it's exploration of more mature themes (politics and death to name a few) through the eyes of the Rabbits of the Sandleford warren is beautifully written and deserves a place in this list. Also Raymond E. Feist's 'Magician' and John Masefield's 'Box of delights' also deserve mention for their indomitable spirit of adventure.
This list is number 237 on my list of the top two hundred lists.
I like Britain's Got Talent Annual 1998
The Life and Times of Michael K by JM Coetzee ought to be there.
`The Ragged Trousered Philanthropists` not included ?! What an oversight by Mr McCrum.

responses.body: Love that book.

comments.body: The Bell Jar - Sylvia Plath ought to be there too.

By the way I have read a lowly 11 of the books noted here so perhaps am not best suited to judge but just feel very strongly that Watership Down offers more to the reader then Wind in the willows - bar the 'piper at the gates of dawn' which admittedly is a deeply emotional/reverential experience.

responses.body: Agreed, Watership Down is really an adult book dealing with very adult themes quite cleverly. It's no hardship to read it to a child whereas WitW is a cartoon made of words.

comments.body: McCrum spent two years doing this?

responses.body: Yep. Full time.
Alright work if you can get it

comments.body: Four superb novels were written in 1915, but not one has appeared since the year 2000. At the risk of sounding like a conspiracy theorist, I think the ruling elite must be putting something in the water supply that inhibits creative thought.

responses.body: At risk of repeating the wise words of others, this list deliberately didn't consider any books published after 2000, a choice made by Mr McCrum.
I think the intention was to cap it at 2000. Every list does need an end, and we have reams of digital space to make the next.
Publishers discovered the easy money available from celebrity writers?

comments.body: Oh it is - apologies!
32 read so far. My list would have been different but included many of the same authors. Would probably have included George Eliott.

responses.body: 21. Middlemarch by George Eliot (1871-2)

comments.body:
I see Joseph Conrad and his inherently racist, 'Heart of Darkness' made the list.

Says a lot you know.

responses.body: It says you don't understand Heart of Darkness, to start with.
Certainly, it was racist. Doesn't stop it being a brilliant novel.
The school of resentment limps on...

comments.body: Stale, predictable, and outdated.

responses.body: you mean your comment?
predictable

comments.body: Only one Wodehouse. Though 'Joy in the Morning' is a fair choice, Right Ho Jeeves just nicks it for me thanks to the prize giving alone.

responses.body: I had never read a Wodehouse - put off by Jeeves I think. But 'Joy in the Morning' was a itself a joy, and I have subsequently read a few more.

comments.body: No Jekyll and Hyde?
Quite a few utterly unreadable tomes here - I've yet to meet anyone who has started Ulysses and managed to finish it

responses.body: Well you haven't met me, but I managed it when I was 17. Not sure how much I got out of it, mind...
You should get out more.

It is a great read, particularly in e-book, as the use of language is truely sublime, but to appreciate it, an ego ok allows you to seamlessly check the meaning of the word and enjoy Joyce's use of it throughout the chapter.
Would recommend trying again.
Me. I've also had a good bash at Finnegan's wake, so there. Yah boo sucks.
then how come you used an apostrophe at the end of "finnegans"
ouch... typo you Lipoleum Hat. Who you think you are the Willingdone on his white harse?

comments.body: 101. Cloud Atlas by David Mitchell (2004)

responses.body: That was utter tripe. Mind you, they have included Midnight's Children, so there would be some similar company.

I'd have David Mitchell in some capacity, though I personally I preferred Ghostwritten. Cloud Atlas seems to be a marmite book. I loved it, but other people say it's terrible, poorly written, etc. Different strokes I guess.

Cloud Atlas was beyond awful. Pretentious tripe written for pseudo intellectuals.
The list is naturally subjective - people have different tastes and that is the top and bottom of it.
Oh lord, not for this list, but I quite enjoyed it. I wish I'd asked you beforehand how to avoid being pretentious or a pseudo intellectual.

comments.body:
What a curious list.

There is a case to be made for Moll Flanders instead of Robinson Crusoe.

Gulliver's Travels is in, and The Hitchhikers Guide To The Galaxy is not -- no arguments from me on that score.

It struck me how many of the titles I'd read, I was made to read at school. And, of the more-recently published half, I'd never heard of at all.

Alice In Wonderland is in. The Wind In The Willows is in, and Winnie The Pooh is not -- I think that's an invitation to further, rather more learned commentary from Alan Bennett.

Brave New World is in, the The Time Machine is not. If I really wished to argue the toss for science fiction, I'd point to a lack of Arthur C Clarke -- Rendezvous With Rama anyone?

Rebecca.

responses.body: Rather than Arthur C Clarke I would suggest the now almost entirely forgotten Olaf Stapledon, and either Last and First Men or Star Maker.
Having read Last and First Men a couple of years ago I can see why Stapledon is almost entirely forgotten.

Sci fi is interesting - I LOVE science fiction, but it is hard to argue that there is very much great literature there. If I had to pick a single favourite s.f. novel I might go for Bester's The Stars My Destination, but it's very much a genre piece.

Arthur C Clarke is an interesting example too. Rendezvous With Rama is perhaps the best imagining of alien life I can think of - surely it would be strange! It puts to shame all those versions of aliens as basically slightly unusual humans. On the other hand, his characters are almost always unconvincing - flat and wooden - no doubt because he is more interested in the ideas than in the people. I can't recall the name of a single character from R.W.R. without looking it up, now - for me, this means that I can't consider Clarke as great literature.
That is the beauty of personal taste! Myself, I find Dickens unreadable. Actually, am I allowed to admit that?

Tiger, Tiger (The Stars My Destination) may be a genre piece but it is a genre of its own and it is hard to imagine that anything could outclass it as a great work of fiction. It may be space opera but it makes all other space opera seem a little trite.
Unlike most other science fiction it is timeless, and people could be forgiven if they thought it was written much more recently than it was.

Clarke, Asimov and many of their contemporaries were good story tellers but terrible writers.

My favourite science fiction prose is that of Cordwainer Smith and James Tiptree, at least in her earlier short stories. Then there is Lafferty who is another one in a class of his own.

hi suddenprayers

it is hard to imagine that anything could outclass it as a great work of fiction.

Anything? Crime and Punishment? Lolita? Nostromo? Middlemarch? Anna Karenina?

Don't get me wrong, I think it's wonderful, and, as you say, hasn't dated at all. I am just not sure I think it is great literature.

Then there is Lafferty who is another one in a class of his own.

I will have to find and read some Lafferty, thanks for the suggestion!

I did mean within the world of science fiction, but I differentiate fiction from literature - different ways of cutting the cakewise. None of the Great Works that I can think of are so exhilarating and relentless.

Lafferty. The collection 900 Grandmothers is a good place to start. If his short stories take you then I'd say Fourth Mansions or The Devil is Dead are the novels to try, but he is at his best with short stories.
There is a website where fans write about their favourite stories. He's a teller of tall stories more than anything else. Look him up on the web.

Lafferty. The collection 900 Grandmothers is a good place to start. If his short stories take you then I'd say Fourth Mansions or The Devil is Dead are the novels to try, but he is at his best with short stories.

Note made - thanks!

" If I had to pick a single favourite s.f. novel ..."

Oh that's easy for me, anything from H. G. Wells works for me

comments.body: Subjective, of course. Personally I found Moby Dick to be the most boring novel I have ever read. Or rather, attempted to read. The sheer tedium made me give up before Ishmael ever makes it to sea.

responses.body:
I thought it one of the greatest novels I've ever read - though there were passages with which I struggled; but that's the nature of opinions about literature. And I think the age at which one approaches some of these books is important - too young, or too old, and they don't appeal. I can remember enjoying Bleak House, for instance, but I doubt I'd have the patience for it now.

The greatest let-down was Lord of the Rings. I recall finally reaching page 1003, shutting the book - and asking myself why the Hell I'd persisted with it. And that proves ........ bugger all.
Is Moby Dick an STD? Perhaps something you get from Muffin the Mule?
Read the first 3 words, skip the next 300 pages and read the last 150, then it's a decent novel.
Impossible to be more boring than Middlemarch
Yep, me too. He spent two pages describing a bench he ended up not sleeping on anyway. C'mon.

comments.body:
I've read twenty-one of these, the oldest being Emma and the most recent, for shame, being In Cold Blood. I didn't count Catch-22 which I attempted to read on three separate occasions but dropped it unfinished every time.

I would agree that, of the sample I have read, every one of those books was impressive and Robert McCrum's analysis was very often spot on so I will bookmark the list and use it for suggested reading in future.

Jesus, I might even give myself another chance to finish Catch-22.

responses.body:
I've read around 90 of them, but then I used to read anything that came my way - and I'm getting on a bit too, so have had the time. I agree with you about Catch-22 - great book it may well be, but I couldn't get through it; there aren't many books I've abandoned completely, but it was one, and Ulysses another. Dice Man was pretty awful, too ...

For sheer, numbing boredom you really need Hermann Hesse - but then, he didn't write in English. I feel a warning is appropriate, nonetheless. Although of course - many will disagree.
Catch-22 would be in my top 10.

Taste is a strange thing. I adored Catch 22 when I read it as a teen, and thought it stood up pretty well when I read it again 10-15 years later. I can't imagine not wanting to continue with it.

I don't often give up on a book - though I confess I did begin to flag in the middle of Moby Dick. I'm glad I continued with it but, on balance, only just.

I've read around 90 of them …

In which case — and bearing in mind that the list was never meant to be definitive — would you rate it favourably?

Interestingly, I also gave up on Steppenwolf but I was only a kid and I dropped a lot of books back in my teenage years. Still, I haven't felt like attempting anything by Hesse since then.

Taste is a strange thing.

Indeed it is which is why a list such as this will always be controversial.

I would also say that I thoroughly enjoyed most of the articles attached to the books listed — and the comments that followed them of course.

... a list such as this will always be controversial

Indeed. I always enjoy such lists if only to give me a possible nudge in the direction of some things I may have overlooked before.

comments.body: I don't know why this list has upset me so.
J G Farrell's trilogy?
Pratchett seems to have been missed which is a shame, and a pity there is no mention of the "Sprouts of Wrath".

responses.body: Robert Rankin - top chap!

comments.body: I would maybe have one of Fleming's Bond novels in there somewhere. And some HP Lovecraft.

Slaughterhouse Five would be #1 on my list, but leaving it off the top 100 entirely is really sort of shocking. The list reads a little bit like a young gentleman's list of adventure books, though I have to compliment you on including Mrs. Palfrey at the Claremont, Elizabeth Taylor (no, not the actress) is unmatched.

responses.body: I thought Slaughterhose 5 was either a rock band or a grown-up version of the Famous Five until I saw the film. Then I read the book and realised what a brilliant writer Vonnegut is.

comments.body:
The hitchhiker trilogy ( all 4 books)
Good list but heavily weighted in older works, yes they've stood the test of time, but just as most baby boomers think music stopped at 1979, literature also carries on.

responses.body: Not really, judging by this list, the largest chunk of which is 19th and early 20th century.
Yes for the first two books, but I think it's a case of diminishing returns after that, at least it was for me.

comments.body: My replacement suggestion has to be Schindler's Ark, by Tom Keneally. Such a brilliant depiction of Germany in WW2.

Occasioned by a mail I received frm my daughter saying she'd just bought Kafka's The Trial and Burroughs The Naked Lunch, I did a similar list of what I call 'rites of passage' books for her; books everyone should have read. Of course this is diffferent from person to person and when I discussed the idea later in the pub - as you do, my learned friends, whose brains were as yet unfogged by the demon drink, came to the conclusion that our book lists were very much informed by the A level syllabus that year and what we read at college (those of us that read English at any rate), as well as what was trendy at the time. Hence, my list included Lord of the Rings, Herman Hesse (Narziss and Goldmund), Mervyn Peake (Gormenghast) and a good smattering of DH Lawrence and Jack Kerouac. You could probably guess my age from that.

responses.body: Mid-50s?
Science students read too you know!
Hesse wrote in German. The game changes if we go outside English.
I know, but I'm talking about set books on the typical English syllabus! I kno sience students kan reed and rite too look at Jonathan Miller....
Close but no ceegar amigo... early 60s!

comments.body: Birdsong should be in with a shout.

responses.body: Sorry, a poor contrivance worth just a tweet.

comments.body:
Where is The Lord of The Rings?
I'm in shock.
Too much 20th century.
Dracula seems a poor choice to me, a third-rate book. Replace it with anything by Richard Ford, Carol Shields, Willa Cather, Annie Proulx, Cormac McCarthy...

responses.body: McCarthy should be on there.Probably Blood Meridian as it has been voted the third greatest American novel of the 20th Century.I don't recommend reading it,though, unless you have a truly strong stomach.Fortunately(?) I have.It's brilliant.

comments.body: Shelley and Peacock, but no Radcliffe?
Just 14. But lists like these are a load of nonsense...
I'd have included one of David Mitchell's books, and American Gods too. It's a good list though.

responses.body: I'd have Great Expectations or A Tale of Two Cities for the obligatory Dickens entry too.
Yes, A Take of Two Cities for structure but Great Expectations for plot

comments.body: Far too many Victorian novels here! Would have had The Kite Runner and Birdsong here too.

responses.body: I thought both average and over-rated. I guess it all comes down to personal choice.
Birdsong was contrived and over long. Never bothered with Kite Runner.

comments.body: Who would have thought that one bloke's opinion of the hundred "best" books could be so divisive, eh? I must admit, there are a lot of books on there that I won't be bothering with, and a fair few that should be on there but aren't. Disappointing that it's mostly white men, but let's face it, most of literature up until the last 30 or 40 years has been white men, not because women lack talent/drive/ability, but because women weren't allowed into the publishing world so easily, and their books have mostly been marketed as "women's fiction", not "literature".
Where's Kurt Vonnegut? Where's 'Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance'? Douglas Adams?

responses.body: I can understand Kurt Vonnegut, Slaughterhouse 5 should be there, but Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenence has aged badly, I always thought the writing was lacking in quality, which is ironic.

comments.body:
Bit disappointed that the compiler preferred At Swim-Two-Birds to The Third Policeman amongst the great Flann O'Brien's works. AS2B is brilliant, but a bit too self-consciously clever-clever. It's also a little difficult to appreciate fully without a decent knowledge of Irish history and, especially, mythology.

The Third Policeman, meanwhile , is more approachable and yet more subversive.
Where is Mervyn Peake?

responses.body: And no Cormac McCarthy either.

comments.body:
Bunyan's A Pilgrim's Progress is a great book to start with. Little read these days outside keen religious circles, but Bunyan had heart and compassion along with his sense of grievance amounting to a persecution complex. The chapter where Christian ascends from the river to The Celestial City is a thrilling moment, even for non-believers like me.

But some very strange preferences here:

- The irritating Emma before the wise Mansfield Park?

- Disraeli's Sybil before the civilised Coningsby?

- David Copperfield with whole sections of awful sentimentality and repetitive emphasis before the humanity of Great Expectations or Little Dorrit or Our Mutual Friend or the terrifying Bleak House?

- Wilkie Collins' The Moonstone with its tedious Miss Clack and forced humour in front of The Woman in White or No Name or Armadale?

- Little Women? A nice book for young teeange girls but come on.......

- The Way We Live Now? No, perennially overrated. Much better stick to The Last Chronicle of Barset or He Knew He Was Right or even Phineas Finn with its 3 fine female character portraits

Heart of Darkness? But where are the full length explorations of human morality Nostromo and Lord Jim?

I've twice found Zuleika Dobson completely unreadable in its archness and snobbery.

The Good Soldier - good but overrated. People wanting to read Ford Madox Ford would be better advised to try the Tietjens trilogy; Some Do Not etc

The Age of Innocence - yes, a great novel and people wanting to read more of Edith Wharton should turn immediately to The House of Mirth - enthralling and frightening in its pinpoint depiction of a dependent woman who on the surface is perfectly free.

Cold Comfort Farm? You have to be joking. Unfunny and stuffy.

But where's Anthony Powell's A Dance to the Music of Time? William Godwin's (father of Mary Shelley) chilling Caleb Williams? George Meredith's The Egoist? One of Joan Aiken's children's books, perhaps The Wolves of Willoughby Chase? (at least we're spared any of the plodding, portentous Tolkien stuff). John Masefield's The Midnight Folk or The Box of Delights? Margery Allingham's The Tiger in the Smoke, a crime novel that soars away into the realms of exploration of an evil heart?

responses.body: Some interesting suggestions, and I really encourage readers to give Caleb Williams a go - it's a thrilling read.
I agree with you on Emma - although I would probably place Persuasion here instead
Little Women for teenage girls? It's for far younger readers!
Thanks. Yes it is: the cat-and-mouse sequences between Caleb Williams and Mr Falkland are wonderfully tense.

Thanks. Well, I love that one, too. Such a matchlessly tender coming together in love at the end between Anne Elliot and Capt. Wentworth as they sit in the writing room in Bath. As regards Emma, I find her and her valetudinarian father and Miss Smith and the Eltons very annoying.
Thank you, Deborah. Oh, is it? But surely the language is pretty difficult for, say, 10 year olds? Quite some time since I read it.
All that tedium reading Emma for just an E...oh, and Middlemarch (so big!) too, great for insomnia. Perhaps Emma should have got married to the Rev. Casaubon.
the good soldier? - overrated? poor old you!

comments.body: Wind in The Willows?

responses.body: Amazing book - beautiful language. Can (and have) read it again and again.

comments.body: More than 21 women wrote or have written great books or "best" books in English! Lists like these strike me as rather silly because what is best for one person is not necessarily best for all. Fine as a guide, but as the ultimate choice, not really.

responses.body: When considering all books written in the English language it's pretty silly to assume you'll have equal numbers written by men as women considering you're going back 3-400 years where women weren't really given the option of becoming writers.
But even in the 20th century he has fewer woman writers than you might expect, and he has missed off some greats. I recommend Rachel Cooke's response to McCrum for another view.

Not silly at all. McCrum featured 20th century writers as well as those going far back in time. Surely he could have included more women IF he had bothered to read their books. Perhaps he should do so now.

He may well have bothered to read their books - that's assuming knowledge about McCrum I certainly don't have. I didn't get the impression this list was 'McCrum : The only 100 books I have read'.

But I think that's besides the point - first off, it's a very safe list so don't expect any wildcard choices, but second, over 400 years of literature there isn't a 50/50 split in gender, in the last 100 years it's starting to look a bit more like it - BUT to provide list of great works in the entire history of written English you have to consider those that have been incredibly influential on the way language and literature has developed, you have to take into account many of the older works whether you like them or not - as such a 50/50 list just doesn't seem likely.

There is nothing wildcard about Willa Cather, Carson McCullers, Eudora Welty, Margaret Mitchell, Pearl Buck, Flannery O'Connor, Marjorie Rawlings, Rebecca West, Olive Schriener, Anita Brookner, Olivia Manning, etc. I haven't said that the list should be 50/50, just that it would have been more balanced had McCrum read more books by women. That said, he did an excellent job discussing the books he considers to be the "best".
agree but for pearl buck! revise your list and it might be more persuasive
